As someone who has worked with an actual virus for completing a 6-month dissertation project, I had to sign around 7 different forms stating that I know what I'm gonna do at the lab, the kind of reagents I'm most likely gonna use, the people I'm gonna work with, the type of microbe that will be studied, and so on. Also, I was given limited lab access where the card only worked for 12 hours as I was doing my Masters and there was 24x7 CCTV surveillance. On top of all that, we all followed a strict protocol in sorting and disposing of any kind of lab waste we generated. So yeah, everyone kinda knew what I was upto from start to finish, and we did everything safely and cautiously.  The idea that people could easily make a deadly world-ending microbe at home in the distant future is rather daft because it is very difficult, risky, and expensive to get your hands on even some of the most basic equipment, enzymes, and even a perfectly harmless microbe.   Kurzgesagt, I do love your videos, but please be careful when talking about anything related to making a home-made bioweapon as it perpetuates the false idea that scientists are out there creating pandemics for the fun of it, and I mean this as a microbiologist.

When I thought chatbot was dangerous weapons
Tldr: Biotech tools may be cheap but you still need to know how to use it. It's easy to mess up and simply fail so it's unlikely the average person would succeed. I'm more concerned about Kurzgesagt's call to wall up information on biotech & genomes.   When I was a highschool student preparing for International Biology Olympiad 6-8 years ago, I experienced firsthand how easy it was to construct a makeshift biotech lab.  Our teachers brought stuff from the university and turned a hall in our dormitory into a makeshift lab. Of course there were no cleanroom or hazmat suits or those kind of things. They just put some machines on the table, kept the reagents / enzymes / DNA solutions in a household fridge, and stored other tools in the corner of the room (micropipettes & tips, microtubes, racks, etc).  We didn't deal with dangerous microbes nor genes, but I do recall doing DNA cleaving with enzymes (not crispr), PCR and electrophoresis.  There were other experiments of course (animal dissection, preparing microscopic slides out of plants, culturing bacteria & fungi, staining bacteria, etc...), but the biotech experiments were the most exciting.  Even though biotech tools, DNA & reagents have become cheaper but it doesn't mean you can conjure up a virus that easily. Properly using them needs particular knowledge, skill & finesse. A simple mistake could fail your whole experiment.  It's like sculpting statues: even with a hunk of marble, a hammer, chisels and knowledge of how a human looks, it is unlikely that the average person would be able to create a statue of decent quality. Even with access to budget biotech tools, reagents, and the virus genome, it is unlikely that the average person would be able to create that virus.  To me, the most alarming part is the call to wall up information on genomes & information on biotech. Much information in the science world is behind a paywall already and even us who were preparing to compete in an international olympiad often resorted to "third party services" to access the information (books & research papers) free of charge.
"Wherever the last pandemic came from"... goes on to explain in detail what likely happened with the last pandemic.
So, information is the viral threat.

I received training and have worked in biotechnology and molecular genetics and I STRONGLY DISAGREE with your claims and conclusions in this video.  1. Free sharing and access to scientific data is a huge driver in discovery and collaboration. I would put it as number one reason we were able to pump out first Covid vaccines so quickly. And it is important to not limit access to this information to scientists as it lock out scientists from less developed countries, citizen scientists and increase distrust of general public with science.  2. It is very hard to get your hands on anything that can really be used for proper genetic engineering. In part current regulations also sometimes hurt scientists in poorer countries. But even in developed nations, there are tons of bureaucratic filters on ordering equipment and reagents and one would think twice before starting even an S1 lab (e.g. working with genetically modified organisms that pose no threat whatsoever) just because of all the pain and constant security audits you have to go through.  3. I do agree that the accessibility of these tools in research and especially education has increased. But that is only a good thing, it bridges the disconnect between the knowledge of fresh graduates and state-of-the-art in academic and industry research. I was so grateful we had opportunity to work with CRISPR-Cas9 in a student lab just 2 years after it was published.  Your video sound like someone trying to push tighter regulations to drown out competition through fear mongering. Very disappointing.

I *STRONGLY* oppose the idea that the blueprints for how to create viruses should be restricted. If we're going to restrict the equipment (and that's a pretty big "if", mind you) then we should be *encouraging* the sharing of such blueprints with as much transparency and detail as possible, up to and including "laymen-terms" documentation so that as many people can understand it as possible.  That way, if/when such a man-made pandemic occurs, the scientific community could leverage crowdsourcing to assist with developing a solution, or very rapidly beef up its research teams from a larger pool of viral engineering amateur volunteers. Further, understanding the diseases that are to be combated is crucial to designing preventative measures and tools to combat such diseases ahead of time. It can even be useful in coming up with unexpected uses and breakaway advances in other fields, such as viruses/bacteria that could transform lead into gold for example. At the absolute LEAST, it helps to deny actual bad actors from hiding their bio-weapon research behind legally sanctioned red tape until it's too late.  Information restriction is to be avoided as much as possible.

This video seems to avoid the argument that if the spread of scientific knowledge is overly regulated, certain interest groups may elect to halt research and development in certain sectors completely. The issue is presented in a very one-sided manner and I suspect that this video was funded by a third party with a clear agenda.
I think the real risk is more like mismanagement of big corporations which have access, resources and license for such things (like how the flaw of Fukushima nuclear power plant was pointed out by an engineer 3-4 decades prior the accident, but the management decided to accept the risk on the ground that it was too expensive to rebuild  and fix). Note that for such thing never black and white, and the risk can never goes to zero, it is about how strict is the procedure (we accept 1 in a mllion years risk, or 1 in 1000 years risk etc). Even big corporations which used to have very high standard can become a bit lax due to cost cutting or profitabillity pressures (Boeing), in addition they might bribe, play politics  or influence those in power (through monetary incentives or other means (help with campaigns etc)). If such things become more and more accessible by wider corporations, then the regulations, and resources to implement them need to keep up. But yeah, the risk can be very high in some cases, beyond what we used to so far, for example, an entire city might be no longer habitable  (not just a few planes went down ). But also though, the benefits (which we have already enjoyed), assuming we can continue managing the risk properly, has been and will always be life changing, it can be said that our survival depends on how we keep progressing on this front (food supply, pollution (plastic, air water), climate change, cure for disease and prevention etc)

This is the one odd video where @kurzgesagt got it wrong. There are so many issues to object to. The next pandemic will not be manmade, this title is as horrible as it is false. The next pandemic will be a zoonotic one, same as the last. The origins of SARS-CoV-2 are not scientifically disputed any more; there is an emerging consensus behind zoonosis based on a detailed body of evidence. The weight of evidence is not only entirely one-sided, it also contradicts, disputes or debunks all plausible lab leak scenarios. Not staying up to date on the science surrounding this controversial topic is really, really bad and the impact of this video will be quite unethical. It creates a false balance between a legitimate scientific hypothesis and a harmful conspiracy myth that has harmed scientists, strained geopolitical relations, and sabotaged pandemic prevention efforts. Nobody says biosafety is not important, but it does not stop at the lab door. The risk of another pandemic coming from spillover is tens of thousands of times more likely for the next years; and even further in the future, when biotech becomes more ubiquitous, it is unclear when lab accidents or bioweapons will pose a higher risk than nature. Next, relying on Kevin Esvelt who is at best a media-savvy contrarian for information and your thrust of the story is so lazy I can hardly believe this reflects kurzgesagt research on this topic. I interviewed dozens of experts in virology, emergent diseases, biosafety and nobody takes Esvelt seriously. Another point to raise is the conflict of interest of Open Philanthrophy, which is an ideological arm of the TRESCREAL cult sponsored by billionaires who rather distract from their misdeeds of the day by marketing a self-serving vision of a future they are creating. If you are not knowing what I am talking about, maybe something to look into. Overall, the biggest issue with this video is not that it get the facts wrong (some they do), but that it got them so decontextualized and put in a framing that is a big distortion on the overall topic, which is pandemic prevention. The real solutions are not about "reigning" in some scientists, but way more complex than that, including addressing the ways we ravage nature and deforestation, the economic incentives of wildlife trade and wildlife smuggling, the lack of any biosafety on too many animal-human interfaces, from cave tourism to hunting to wildlife markets to backyard and factory farming. All this video did, like so much media around this topic before, is to seed suspicions and distrust about science and scientists in the general public, while presenting them a red herring for pandemic prevention that takes away oxygen from the real lessons and actions required that should have been implemented by now. 3:32 No. We do know. It was a random mutation. Not a lab leak.   The gene sequences of bat affecting corona virus are nearly identical to human affecting viruses with only a few random alterations to the spike proteins allowing them to bind to human ACE-2 receptors. This indicates a likelyhood of prolonged exposure to infected bats who have a myriad of diseases that took an opportunist approach to a new host.  A lab version would have obvious signs of tampering, large swaths of code completly different from what was present in the natural virus code for example. In addition a lab made virus to affect humans that had viable viral RNA inside it could only ever make sense as a deliberate bio-weapon. Much like nuclear weapons that have extremely deliberate, precise engineering and physisics requirements to function, a virus has extremely precise requirements for viable gene mutations and protein binding, anything less than wouldn't be viable.  Any lab serious about developing such a thing would never release it without first making it as deadly as possible as well as a vaccine to use as leverage and a safe guard for themselves.  That isn't what SARS-COV 19 is like.   A natural virus rarely has high lethality as too much lethality inhibits contagiousness. Instead natural viruses like high infectivity and low lethality to promote lots of infections and longevity for the virus, which is what SARSâ€COV 19 does.  6:57 NO. ABSOLUTELY NOT, we don't need censorship or the thought police. We should assume the information is spreading freely already among evil people already and spread it as freely as possible among ourselves to aid in development of technology relating to detection and destruction of viruses.
5:33 When you say "we're creating an environment in which it's increasingly easy for anyone to create a weaponized virus in their backyard, this is scary", that's missing the forest for a tree: that we're in fact creating an environment in which it's increasingly easy for anyone to access goal enabling knowledge and capability in ANY domain. As individual capability increases thanks to exponential progress and wealth distribution in all domains, the implications are very uncomfortable: Short of a draconian and authoritarian control and alignment dystopia, the risks associated with the freedom of individuals able to command the scientific outcomes of a Kardashev Type I civilization might be a great filter candidate.

Honestly, I echo the sentiments of most of the folks commenting with their issues. This videos main fact checker is also one of its main sources-that presents an inherent conflict of interest because while they're likely knowledgeable, they're more likely to steer the material towards their own conclusions.  Theres also the general scaremongering-while we don't yet know for 100% sure where COVID came from, it seems increasingly likely (and in the eyes of most of the scientific community) that it was a spillover event. Lab leaks aren't unheard of but it does feel disingenous and honestly kind of irresponsible to make such a gross sensationalist thumbnail for cheap clicks when y'all should be above that. Especially since the fear is of home bio hackers but then a complex lab setup is in the thumbnail and the dudes suit is filled with mystery virus. Even if the fear is of homebrew stuff, you're directly implicating labs that have complex procedures in place for containment and study of novel or GOF mutants.   The video itself is also relatively....kinda off. Others have noted the lack of birds, rewatching the video I noticed...a vial rolling off the table which is a gross subtle detail that implies irresponsibility on the part of people looking for viral agents despite that...being an important part of surveillance? Which ties in with the general theme of distrust of scientists if they're not the exact right kind I guess.  Theres also the ties to a nebulous megadonor that honestly seems kind of shady. I get you've done some good vids sponsored by the Gates foundation but this feels different, especially with how off the video is. The philanthropy group in question is also pretty shady and nebulous so I don't think their money was worth it.   As someone in the microbial sciences, its not nearly as easy to construct these sorts of pathogens as you're making it out to be. This would require complex sequencing equipment, cell culture equipment, a team of folks who know what they're doing, reagents, power, etc. It also would require extensive testing which means access to cell culture but also rodents and likely eventually human subjects. Which....is out of the reach of most folks to put it mildly-and given companies track product its likely a government agency could connect the dots some. And ALSO-to produce this mystery virus, you'd need mass production systems which are difficult to maintain and keep from contamination even in professional facilities...not to mention dispersal issues.   Also sharing information is a cornerstone of science! How are we supposed to prepare for new pandemics if scientific data is sequestered so that multiple labs can't work on it? What if another lab has a key insight but they get frozen out due to petty rivalries and that slows down research that precedes a pandemic related to that virus? Should journals not share important data about existing dangerous pathogens just because someone might misuse it? Of course not, because a better understanding of a pathogen by multiple labs can advance scientific understanding and help with treatment or vaccination etc! Should we just not teach young people about science to avoid one of them maybe possibly doing something bad? Should you have to be employed at the right university or corporation to be allowed to access forbidden knowledge? That strikes me as foolish and backward because that knowledge might strengthen them and prime them to become leaders in their field earlier than they would have, allowing them to benefit humanity sooner.   And thousands of pandemics? Seriously? Do you think government's aren't going to crack down incredibly hard if even one pathogen escaped from some dudes garage? Or tighten biosecurity if they find a small lab thats been messing with a pathogen? This is kinda abdurd.   There are legit biosecurity discussions and issues to be hashed out with biotech and homegrown stuff but this video just feels poorly put together and sloppy. I'd honestly say you should just return the money, take this video down, and try to be better because this video legitimately shakes my confidence as a long time fan of your channel.

This video was incredibly disappointing. Not only is it not educational, it is fear mongering and inaccurate.   I have worked in biosafety levels 1-2+, have friends who work in level 3 facilities, and have learned about the workflow of level 4 faculties. I have also worked in a virus lab. Honestly, I have a hard time pinning down anything in this video that is actually accurate. Yes, gain of function research is highly controversial and potentially dangerous - thank goodness it rarely takes place, and even then in extremely controlled environments. No, you cannot order viruses in the mail. IF you manage to sneak buying lab equipment to your home - the unlicensed application of which is highly illegal - the types of viruses you could make at home would be quite harmless. Inject your worst enemy with a properly-designed Lentivirus and maybe it will give them cancer eventually - though even this is highly unlikely. Even making those requires far more equipment than you can buy for the price of a car - otherwise your virus would degrade because of impure water, or suboptimal storage conditions, among other factors.  Material you order is strictly tracked, there are special contractors to hire to produce negative pressure ventilation environments, more to install high-power outlets - so many things wrong with this video. I tried shipping non-pathogenic RNA for analysis recently and it was stopped at the border and allowed to degrade because I missed one piece of paperwork - I cannot imagine the hassle of mailing something that is actually pathogenic.   This is not to say that there is nothing to worry about, but we can have an honest and thoughtful discussion about the actual hazards rather than devolve into paranoid schizophrenia.   I like this channel but something is very off with this video. Happy to answer a few questions or clear up some confusion.

The idea of adding yet another slice of human knowledge to the forbidden list of "infohazards," where the government becomes the gatekeeper of information it deems hazardous, is itself extremely hazardous. Any suggestion that we ought to expand the list of infohazards had better be founded on a potential catastrophe that is extremely well evidenced - the more spectacular the claim, the more spectacular the evidence must be in support of it.  This video fails to meet that high standard, or even the standards of a normal Kurzgesagt video.   Most problematic is that the keystone to Kursgesagt's case is the following claim, "Thousands of scientists can simply order the DNA of infectious virus samples online to experiment with them. Assembling these into an artificial virus in 2023 costs about as much as a new car, including all the lab equipment," which is evidenced from a single citation of Kevin M. Esvelt, (2022): â€œDelay, Detect, Defend: Preparing for a Future in which Thousands Can Release New Pandemicsâ€ published by the Geneva Center for Security Policy.  Kurszgesagt states that the script for this video was based on the forgoing paper, which itself does not appear to be a peer-reviewed paper. The author of that paper is also the one individual Kurszgesagt consulted to fact check their script. That's right, the author of the major claims of this video was tasked with fact-checking the rephrasing of his own work.   In addition, the source material fails to strongly evidence its own unreviewed claims. In the above-referenced paper, Mr. Esvelt admits, "While sequenced viruses are widely accessible, pandemic proliferation and misuse cannot yet occur because we lack key knowledge: there are still no credible examples of viruses likely to cause new pandemics." Moreover, the author acknowledges that the screening he proposes as a solution is already occurring voluntarily and he only presumes there to be loop holes and fails identify any.  "the International Gene Synthesis Consortium, an industry group concerned about the prospect of misuse, screen customers and DNA synthesis orders for hazards at considerable expense, it is easy to find nonmembers that presumably do not."  Some will present what they believe to be a counter-point, acknowledging that they can't prove the problem exists, but what if it does and we do nothing to mitigate it? Think of the world-ending consequences!" This is an emotional appeal. It also avoids the requirement that those making an initial claim accept the burden of proof to prove their claim.   Imagine if we so easily allow our governments to close off entire realms of human knowledge on nothing more than the unevidenced possibility of disaster? How far will our tolerance of that kind of intervention shift towards 'better safe than sorry'? If it shifts enough towards 'better safe than sorry' then we risk the list of forbidden knowledge growing with every new administration in the federal (or your equivalent) office. The new additions will be predictably partisan. Some great additions your disfavored political party might add to the list of knowledge you can't possess are as follows:  1. Encryption that prevents an information gatekeeper from determining if you are disseminating or obtaining an infohazard; 2. Methods to safety induce an abortion; 3. Blueprints for 3-d printed guns,; 3. Information released by government whistleblowers.  4. Sexual education materials that discuss contraception, abortion, sexual activities between individuals of the same sex, and so on. 5. Guidelines on nonviolent resistance and peaceful protest tactics to promote civic engagement and safeguard the right to peaceful assembly, and counter-measures against counter-measures employed by the government in opposition to those things. 6. Knowledge about harm reduction strategies and safe drug use practices to mitigate the risks associated with substance abuse. 7. Information critical of climate change theory, or any other theory where criticism has been equated with murder.   Your equivalent of the Supreme Court might stop some of those infringing violations of your right to speak freely, or it might not.   In summary, Kurszgesagt hasn't met its burden of proof and their due diligence on this video falls below their ordinary work and fails to achieve due diligence.  Your emotional reaction to the scary claims made in the video is not evidence of their accuracy. We should resist being compelled to accept gatekeeping of human knowledge for no other reason than we're scared of it.

The solution is exactly opposite, the most dangerous research like gain of function research should be done jointly and publicly in select extremely safe labs with collaboration from rivaling powers so that everyone gets to chance to study and develop countermeasures.  Nobody likes bioweapons, there is no truly safe way to deploy them that is guaranteed not to backfire catastrophically. Every country would love to be privy to others' research and the arms race is based on the fear of not being behind with logic of mutually assured destruction like nuclear weapons. There is a key difference tho. While developing bioweapons the crucial part is developing countermeasures for yourself - something that is impossible for nuclear weapons, if research is shared then it is no longer bioweapon development since you cannot weaponize it because everyone gets the jointly developed countermeasures, it becomes beneficial to all.

I work at a community biology lab and it's actually pretty difficult to get virus, even just as gene DNA, even for non-pathogens. Then, as others have pointed out, you still need to assemble them. There is already a decent amount of due diligence and international collaboration, especially by the large biotech distributors that currently dominate the market. This is one case where the inevitable centralization under capitalism leads to safer systems.  This is of course at the cost of access to the poorest communities and we could intentionally design regulatory systems while also maintaining the spread of knowledge and access to technological resources.  This also ignores viral ecology...the reason that existing deadly viruses like ebola are much easier to contain than COVID has to do with differences in virulence: a long incubation time and a large proportion of asymptomatic infections. Often the traits that allow a virus to easily and quickly spread throughout a population also reduce its virulence as dead hosts (usually) can't spread the virus.

As scientist working in a microbiology laboratory, I can tell you it is nearly impossible to get your hand on something dangerous online. The only way to get dangerous bacteria or viruses involve going through an tremendous amount of administrative and certification work impossible to do if you are not in university or big company. The same goes for bacteria and viruses modification, you not only need the equipment (that isn't easy to get as it is expensive and for some them, you need certification and authorization too), but also the people to work with (terrorists are rarely academics). And the cherry on top of the icing, you need to justify why you would like to have such bacteria or viruses to work with. So it is not really for tomorrow (nor the day after), people will be able to make something dangerous in their garage.  The good news is all the tools you propose to put to stop new pandemic are already done since... decades... Next inform better yourself! The one take away I have from the difference in nuclear weapons and bio weapons. Is that to get nuclear material it is very hard to get uranium ore, and requires large scale specialized industrial  processes to get weapon grade material. Building it after is still hard but then becomes simpler. So security is on the raw materials, less so on knowledge. A bio weapon requires a relative trained individual some specialized lab and just one small sample.

With great power comes great responsibility. If you donâ€™t believe this statement just look at the majority of people with power; most of them abuse and/or misuse their power in some way.  Side note: I specifically separate abusing and misusing power as a way to differentiate the severity. Not all misuse of power causes harm.   My rule of thumb:  Correct use = responsible use of power. Only used with good intentions and extreme care to minimize potential damage.  Misuse: Irresponsible use but doesnâ€™t cause harm. Like cheating in a video game but the only cheats you use only effect you (and thereâ€™s no secondhand effects + all chain reactions only effect you)  Abuse: negligence and misuse of power that causes harm to others. That includes indirect harm, direct harm, secondhand effects, longterm consequences, chain reactions, etc.  Edit: I donâ€™t have an opinion on necessary risks and necessary sacrifices. Itâ€™s not my place to judge those decisions and it would be insensitive of me to judge them.

Itâ€™s funny how the title of this video is â€œThe Next Pandemic Will Be Man Madeâ€ when this past pandemic was already man made. Grown in a lab from gain of function research. ğŸ˜‚
This video felt incredibly weird. Not only the structure, lack of faces, the alarmist tone, the lifelessness of the animation...    What feels the weirdest to me is the sub-par sources, and the fact that the main source for this video was paid by the same organization that paid for this video. I will explain. (I apologize for how long this is.)   I looked through the sources that they listed, and out of the 52 times they source something, 9 times Kurzgesagt sourced the same book. And of those 52 sources, only, to my eye, 13 were about the manipulation and study of bacterial/viral genes in any capacity. (There were 6 on nuclear weapons, for comparison).   And about the claim of easy access to both materials and knowledge that the argument hinges on? There is one source about concerns related to easy access to genetic information, and one about easy access to DNA editing equipment.  The source about easy access to genetic information (other than the book this video is based on) brings up several good examples of the risk involved with being incredibly open with knowledge about viruses and bacteria. It brings up case studies where scientists edited viruses, and published their results, in a way that was a cause for concern. Such as editing a mousepox virus so that it could bypass an existing vaccine, and publishing what gene editing was done to make that possible.   The source does show an opposing opinion, which says that those with access to that information can then plan to counteract such a gene, if a virus like it were to be released on human populations. And this source, while intriguing, focuses wholly on the formal, laboratory-based research. Which this video decisively does not address, instead talking about, essentially, 'backyard biologists'.  Which the second source talks about. This source isn't a peer-reviewed paper, or published in a scientific journal, unlike the first one. This source talks about DIY CRISPR kits - at home DNA editors. But the source makes no mention of infectious diseases, saying that these kits can ".... make bacteria and yeast change colour, produce a fragrance or live in inhospitable places, but their lives are short." The source says that there is very little that can be actually done to bacteria beyond this. Which does not back up the claim that pretty much anyone could have access to powerful gene-editing capabilities.  As for the book - the primary source of this video. I am not inclined to read it in its entirety, but I will provide relevant quotes they listed, and break them down.   For materials access: "DNA constructs of length sufficient to generate infectious 1918 influenza virus can now be obtained for US$1,500; coronaviruses cost approximately US$2,000, but typically must be enzymatically stitched together by hand prior to virus generation, limiting (for now) the number of capable individuals to those also skilled at modern biotechnology. The laboratory equipment and reagents required for these tasks can typically be obtained for less than US$50,000.â€ So... It doesn't mention who has access to such materials (making it seem like anyone could order it off the internet), nor does it say how easy it is to edit such diseases to make them bio-weapons. That is the only mention of material access.  For information access: â€œSecurity concerns are less salient in the current culture of the life sciences, as evidenced by the number of projects explicitly intending to create, identify, and publicly share a list of viruses ranked by apparent threat level.â€ "Under the current system, a scientist who warns the world of a pandemic-class agent inadvertently provides widespread access to skilled "lone wolf" actors who rely on commercial DNA synthesis, as well as well-resourced actors who do notâ€ His argument appears to be that publishing information about potential pandemic-creating agents or mutations gives people the information to create them... Without considering the opposite side of that coin - it also gives people the information to stop them.  Overall... Not very convincing, to me, at least. The many comparisons to nuclear weapons, in his quotes, feel odd to me. It's the comparison between life, an ever-evolving, extremely complex system, to nuclear bombs and their proliferation, which is exclusively a weapon or energy source. There are no "cures" or "vaccines" for a nuclear explosion, but there *is* for viruses and bacteria. So while there is pretty much only danger in the democratization of information about nuclear weapons, there is undoubtedly upsides to the information on diseases. The collaboration and wealth of information that scientists had on the subject is precisely what led to the super fast discovery of a COVID-19 vaccine!  But, solely the arguments aside... This was a weird video, very unlike most of Kurzgesagt's. The changing of the title and thumbnail (which is done solely for engagement - and Kurzgesagt hasn't shown they cared for that before). The fact this video was paid for by the same organization that paid the man who wrote the book this video is based on, essentially saying exactly what's in said book, the weirdly lackluster sources compared to normal videos, the bad analogy in nuclear, not looking at an opposing viewpoint, not going in-depth about something crucial (like who has access to viral materials), the odd structure, the sub-par animation.... I won't read too much into it, but I can say confidently that this is not the standard quality that I expect from Kurzgesagt, and that I am very disappointed in them for this.  Thank you for reading this. Sorry that it's so long... But Kurzgesagt is a huge channel, doing a lot of good, I think, so I don't want them to go down the route of whatever led to this video being created.  Edit: Spelling mistakes

Regulating genetic information downloads is not the long-term way to go. We can regulate nuclear materials since they're physical objects. However, due to the replicable nature of information, it is merely far more difficult to regulate, since the black market exists and can always sell you dangerous virus DNA if you wanted to, let alone that certain public agencies may purposefully weaponize biotechnology regardless of any public regulation. Therefore, regulating the information is more of a security-by-obscurity kind of solution.  In the sense of information security and cryptography, the most viable, effective, and once for all solution is to battle on the defender side: making bio-safety infrastructures, facilitating vaccine developments, or even, with some more sci-fi technology, encrypting our own DNA and implementing zero-trust systems within our body -- and these are the examples corresponding to the latter two options mentioned in the video. These techniques are what we have been doing for decades for the safety of our internet and computers, and we will probably do it for ourselves one day in the future.

I'm disappointed with the statement "whether COVID-19 was natural or came from a lab is still up to scientific debate". It's not. The SARS-COV-2 virus has no unique properties that lend itself to being an artificially created virus. There's also no evidence in favour of the lableak hypothesis.  Finally, new diseases coming into existence is something which happens frequently in nature. Saying that there's credibility to the lableak hypothesis is like saying that the recent earthquakes in Syria & Turkey were man-made by detonating nuclear bombs under the surface. It's an overly complicated explanation to a problem with an obvious solution. If something has happened countless times before humans (and will continue to happen countless times after us), you better have exceedingly strong evidence to suggest this time it was caused by humans. Said evidence, does not exist.  There's also the fact that the lableak hypothesis is also extremely politically motivated but that's beside point.

This video is full of irresponsible nonsense, which is frankly very disappointing coming from Kurzgesagt. Nuclear weapons proliferation is a massive problem. We're dealing with the fundamental forces of nature here. Security through obscurity does not work. The first people who invented nuclear weapons were able to delay their acquisition by other states for a few years, but that did not last. Nukes are everywhere now. The last thing we need is proliferation of viral zero-days caused by researchers being afraid of sharing their findings.

On top of that, you have to consider the overall danger level. People just aren't that hell-bent on destroying one another.  Don't believe me?  Stop and think, how many people in, say, the past 10 years of your life have you walked past? Every single one of those people could have killed you. A short blade unexpectedly to your throat, you would have bled out in seconds. Now, how many of those people tried? None? Gee, does that sound like a world full of people who are willing to kill you? How many times have people set your house on fire while you were asleep?  It's trivially easy to do, and they've had every single night of every single day to give it a go, and all the people who live around you or are even just passing through the area had the opportunity.  You get it?  It's not hard to kill people.  But, there are simply not very many people who are willing to do it.  Comparing bioweapons to nuclear weapons is fundamentally flawed in very serious ways.  First, giving people information about how to develop nuclear weapons does not aid in defending against nuclear weapons.  With bioweapons, it does. Nuclear weapons can be targetted, and defending against them is nearly impossible, while bioweapons can not be targetted (which destroys any person using them to get an advantage for themselves because it will kill them too) but can be defended against IF the knowledge exists on how to guard against them - which is the whole point of gain of function research.  It is completely ridiculous to propose that you could prevent someone who wanted the genetic sequence of a deadly virus from getting it.  They would only need 1 person infected with that virus, or some tissue from them, and then they could sequence it themselves in a garage.  Then, you would have this big system "controlling access to the information" and total confidence that the bad actor definitely doesn't have the sequence, so you would not look at them as a potential danger.  Meanwhile they're running breeder reactors in their basement to try to bring about the apocalypse.  It's just a gigantic waste of resources that doesn't actually protect or help anyone.

As a molecular biologist working on gene therapy using viral vectors, I can assure you that it is extremely difficult to avoid being tracked when ordering genetic components. Even though our biosafety level 1 is officially defined as "non-pathogenic material that is unlikely to harm the environment and humans," we are still obligated to report each case to the appropriate authorities and maintain meticulous documentation of our biosafety level 1 experiments. These experiments, which are considered safe according to the defined biosafety standards, are subjected to frequent monitoring by regulatory bodies. As you can imagine, things get even more strict when working with higher biosafety levels like viruses that target human cells. This time the kurzgesagt clip is more entertaining than informative.

"There's no reason scientists today can't handle really dangerous biological technology in a similar way..."  Sorry, but no. There is every reason. Yet another use case for AI. Who would have thought that building something that can do superhuman thinking in narrow domains could be leveraged anywhere with disastrous results when unchecked!? *shocked* We're already using AIs to do search space work, wherein they generate candidates for research that are promising based upon success criteria inferred from pattern matching across all known pathogens. This is happening in materials science to find superconductor candidates, materials with high tensile strength, tunable optical properties, and, yes, in biology for both pharmaceuticals and viruses. That AI software is only going to become more robust and the source code is not that hard to get a hold of. A bioterrorist with a drive to end humanity and a mediocre intellect could, in a few short years, engineer a capable virus and then order the parts required (all innocuous) and do the final assembly. It's one of the major three human-born existential threats we face: AGI, nanotech, and biotech. Each has far more bad outcomes than good, and each is disastrously imbalanced in a game theoretic sense: it's far easier for the attacker than the defender.

The human genome project was "completed" in 13 years, but it did not read the full human genome. It was an amalgam that was sort of a rough draft of a typical human genome and not a full human genome. It's amazing to me that a channel like this, which I respect in many ways -- though they make significant errors sometimes and have bad opinions masquerading as science sometimes -- can make a claim like that without giving any nuance. It means they were unaware or didn't care about the subtleties, which are both terrible, since the argument that immediately follows leans upon the claim. Anyway, back to the point: a full human genome has *still* not been sequenced today, though it's expected to happen this year. Google into this a bit for more information. We basically in the past have just found a template for the human genome and then we look for specific alleles in cheap lab tests to guess at specific genes within that template, but that leaves a lot of room for missing genes and surprises. No person in the history of humankind has had an accurate, full account of their dna as yet, but we're basically there now.

As someone who regularly orders and has DNA synthesised for genetic engineering research, this is kind of misinformation. The companies that provide these synthesis services are actually pretty strict on who they will supply to and what they will make. They run your requested DNA sequence through multiple databases (especially the virus parts, iGem, NCBI, etc) and will not produce it if there are issues. I've had innocuous sequenced flagged because there was homology with toxin proteins, and had to liaise with their engineers/technicians.  There were other less than accurate claims here, but that one stood out as particularly egregious.

Eh the whole concept of "We should track people and limit peoples ability to access information cause bad things could happen" Is a dicey topic, and has issues that clash with fundamental freedom of speech rights in many western countries. If anything that will be the stumbling block that will inhibit any controls who does what with biological technology.  Also I take issue with the opinion that we've been "responsible" and have limited nuclear proliferation through limiting access to information when its the fact that getting a hold of the materials to make a weapon that has more been the issue. The information to make a bomb is easily obtained, its the materials and production of those materials that's extremely difficult to get a hold of or make without killing yourself, or tipping off other countries onto what you're doing. To that point look up the case of boy scout who built a functional nuclear reactor in his shed.   You could conceivably control it through a licensing program, but that too has its limits, and relies on countries caring enough to license people to perform genetic work, and or the ability to control the manufacture of equipment needed to do such work. That also falls apart if the equipment is also easy to make on your own.   This also somewhat mirrors efforts of gun control, as the information, equipment needed, and materials to make your own firearm is freely available and difficult to stop.

The iPhone analogy is deeply flawed (and it's a pity your Apple brandism caused you to miss an amazing parallel).  A phone isn't simply parts - it's also an OS and Apple guards both parts tightly making "from scratch" clones as you suggest extremely difficult without having an actual iPhone from which to harvest key parts. Even then the security in their system, which extends down to locking each core part to each other making replacing even one core part (not to mention repair) almost impossible, would make this even harder still. Exactly the OPPOSITE of your 'share and make easy' proposal.  On the other hand, there's a legal, open-source version of Android (AOSP - Android Open Source Project) based on the same code that runs in retail Android phones with a few missing but not essential parts. Android phones are based on retail and easily obtained parts. In theory at least, anyone can make an Android phone from scratch because core knowledge and code is shared by everyone. Just like your proposed mechanism for biodata.  I know creatives LOVE to shove Apple references in wherever they can, but this is one of those times where that urge literally undermined your message.

- The rapid progress of biotechnology has given us the tools to manipulate living organisms, resulting in advances in healthcare and agriculture. However, this same progress has made it easier for individuals with malicious intent to create weaponized viruses. - The sharing of information in the field of biotechnology, including the genetic data of dangerous viruses, makes it possible for well-meaning scientists to inadvertently or irresponsibly share blueprints for creating highly destructive viruses. - The accessibility of synthetic DNA and equipment needed to rebuild viruses, as well as the lack of comprehensive tracking, raises concerns about the ease with which anyone could create a weaponized virus. - The consequences of a weaponized virus being unleashed could be devastating, potentially causing pandemics that would lead to the loss of millions or even hundreds of millions of lives. The UV illustration is a bit misleading. High Powered UV lamps like those are exclusively used in sensitive bio laboratories for a reason. Sure, they're powerful enough to kill any microorganisms inhabiting the air but also powerful enough to degrade the other compounds in the air into more dangerous materials. Not to mention the cancer you'll get from the UV exposure damaging your cells. You'll get away with it if you're using it for some sort of decontamination procedure before going into a sterile workplace but for general use, it is really not advised.

While I love y'all's videos, this one is dangerously inaccurate. Following the COVID-19 pandemic and the mass disinformation campaign surrounding it's origins, virologist around the world have seen their field (and at times their safety) put at risk. It is not as easy as the video makes it out to be to source pathogenic materials. All repositories I know of, as a virologist, require a university laboratory address in order to even deliver any ordered materials. Repositories also require additional documentation, such as IBC approvals, before the order is processed. Most, if not all, repositories are also government run; this empowers them to confirm the identities of those ordering pathogenic materials.   Beyond the incorrect information presented with regards to sourcing infectious and pathogenic materials, the video also shares information regarding prevention of disease using techniques not approved for human consumer use. This can easily convince viewers to purchase UV lights and place them in their homes without the proper understanding and safety precautions needed to use UV.   Again while I love your videos, this one is particularly disappointing and I encourage the channel to take it down and revise it with science-backed facts regarding the dangers of infectious agents AND the countermeasures already in place to prevent malicious acts using them.

Molecular biologist here, and my area of study was in vaccines and counter-bioterrorism. As with all Kurzgesagt videos, this one is very on-point and accurate. However, there is something I came to realize working in this field--which is that humanity is only going to survive rapidly advancing technology if it creates a society that eliminates the causes of radicalization and bad actors.  Simply put, the amount of damage a single bad actor can do has advanced exponentially over the last thousand years, and that's only going to advance further along with technology. Taking actions like regulating access to select DNA/RNA is only going to go so far when people can literally build bio weapons using common soil organisms and readily-accessible materials.  The only long-term way we're going avoid some very doomsday scenarios is by removing the things that create bad actors, and we do that by having an insanely robust mental and physical health system, virtually zero income inequality, virtually zero religious extremism, and basically ensure everyone is as content and fulfilled as possible.
Yes, I agree it can be dangerous to have biotech be this open, but this danger is greatly exaggerated here, and definitely takes away from the first part "free and open exchange of information has greatly accelerated development". We need to be wary of any attempt to lock down biology by corporations that would rather have a monopoly on research to make a profit. Science being free from profit motive has got humanity where it is today, we can't kill that progress.  All this being said, Open Philanthropy's interest is with corporations wishing to turn biotech into a walled garden under the guise of "safety". I really want to believe Kurzgesagt when you say they have no narrative control, but the overlapping narrative is too suspicious.

while the theoretical danger of a man made virus is real, this video is pretty overblown. Most notably, all of the "dangerous virus research" happening is rapidly improving our abilities to treat and respond to these viruses, so in actuality it's making them less dangerous. And while certain types of viruses can spread very quickly, they really don't have the level of danger associated with them that other bioweapons do: spreading pneumonic plague or anthrax (both bacteria) is just as easy and much more targeted; weaponizing a pandemic would only really be possible if you already had a vaccine, and if you did, it means it's not that hard to create one, and even then, a single mutated strain could screw everything up.  Viruses love to mutate, and generally they mutate to be more infectious and less pathogenic (viruses want to spread and survive, killing their host isn't the goal, which is why so many deadly viruses have come from animals, we aren't the species they are used to). these viruses will always be basically uncontrollable, and we know so little about their actual inner workings right now that figuring it out poses way more benefits than risks, such as finding new antiviral drugs.

As much as I like the accurancy of Kurtzgesagt videos this one I cannot agree with... Yes, it is possible to create novel virus that is much much more easy to spread or kill its subject, but realization of such project is extremly difficult.  First, to know your virus truly is "better" you need to test it... on subjects of interest... and if we mean humans it is difficult to find many individuals to test your virus on. Keeping control on your experiment while keeping it in secret... doesnt seem easy with how much information is monitored today. Second, artificially adding "better" genes into a virus to make it deadlier is again, difficult. You are more likely to kill a virus than making it stronger using this method. Its much easier to just let nature do this work for you and use some controlled environment to let your virus spread and evolve, forcing natural selection to be deadlier and easier to spread... but eventually, if you let this virus out it will probably evolve back into a form that does not kill its host as this strategy is non optimal. The most optimal solution would be (just like with any other pandemic virus in history) to make itself easier to spread but also less deadly. Viruses are constantly evolving and yours will too, its not something that will stay the same throughout a pandemic. Third, you can have easy acces to dangerous information but if you cant understand what to do with it it is not a useful information and to be able to create a deadly virus you will need some experties within the field. Fourth, you wont be able to create such virus in short time. It could be decades till you find your perfect killer. Till then your target population might change/evolve/adapt and with it your virus wont be that much effective anymore.  It seems to me it is much easier to create a bomb and use it than creating a virus that might work.

The reason nuclear technology is kept under control is mostly because of how hard it is. Making a nuclear bomb is easy, getting enough of the fissile material is really hard. You need a large quantity of uranium ore, process it, and enrich it, you may also want nuclear reactors to convert it into plutonium and to get tritium if you want something more advanced than the Hiroshima bomb. It is a very expensive process that only state actors can afford. The most likely result for an individual or small group being careless with nuclear technology is that they irradiate themselves, and unlike viruses, radioactive material don't reproduce uncontrollably.

Cochlear implants don't connect directly to the brain; they bypass the middle ear by sending sound vibrations through the bone of the skull. Those vibrations are picked up by the cochlea the way it normally would if the middle ear wasn't malfunctioning. They're a powered microphone connected to a metal stud anchored in your bones. Another name for them is "bone-anchored hearing aids." I currently use a Bluetooth headset that works similarly by touching pads against the side of my head.

For anyone who wants to know what they were referring to, the research they were talking about is called Gain of Function Research and it's the Government Sanctioned process of essentially weaponizing natural viruses in order learn how viruses become more deadly. Comparing this technology to nuclear is actually pretty absurd because no one can build a nuclear bomb in their basement and contrary to what others in the comments have said, claiming it's not incredibly easy now, that's irrelevant, it's that it's about to be. Tools like DNA printers and online databases of viruses are becoming incredibly prevalent, the sequence for The Spanish Influenza was a published online in 2004 and a team was able to recreate the horse pox virus from scratch in under a year and that was in 2017, the technology has only gotten faster since then and it's only going to get far faster. You don't even need almost any resources to do this stuff and the scary thing is a lot of people not motivated by political gain have plenty of resources to do this. Havent actually worked in the feild yet, but im at uni, and this sounds A LOT more fear mongery than it probably should. The idea that "anyone" can just access the materials and information needed to create a biological weapons program is slightly farfetched, to say the least. Although i cant speak much for the US or other places, the UK seems to have plenty of regulations and steping stones that need to be crossed befor you can get a bottle of smallpox out of the freezer. And i have a feeling the rozzers might have some questions if you order a "DNA printer 3000" for "Home use".
The lab leak theory has been scientifically disproven many times in highly-cited articles. The intelligence agencies are using the wrong tools for the job to determine whether or not it came from gain of function research. Simply looking at the rate of mutation, signatures of modification, and the lineage by which it evolved, everything points to it coming directly from an animal. It's still possible a sample taken from an animal was stored, and an accident triggered the event, but the scientists must have done nothing but frozen it.  As someone with a background in biology, I take issue with the casual nature of discovery and engineering this video takes in biotech. Randomly stumbling upon a mutation that is both harmful and can rapidly spread would take thousands of dollars of animal models, not to mention expensive facilities to house them. To do so without animal testing would be as likely as encountering a novel virus in the wild: not impossible but not significantly more risky than our current landscape.  Genetic engineering still requires expensive reagents, expensive equipment, and at least some tricks of the trade. There are biohackers that can replicate some easy techniques, but there is a huge difference between making something that survives in a lab and something that can spread in the environment.  But the tone of the video is correct: we must create a robust framework of ethics and laws to prevent rogue agents from developing terrible new bioweapons. The biggest reason they haven't been developed is it's like a gun that points at you and your enemy. And once fired, the bullet can morph into a canonball or a nerf dart. They are horrible as weapons for states.  But for terrorism, they are perfect. The collateral damage can hide the intention of an attack, and the unknown nature of it can inspire fear. I have no idea how we mitigate attacks from larger terrorism networks other than what we must do for pandemics: develop tools to stop them and set up a network of monitoring stations everywhere as a measure of global security.

After seeing the video and going through the sources, there are a few things that I don't think were correct in the video.  The main publication the video is based on is not a scientific publication and is not peer-reviewed. It displays a clear bias against biotechnology in general, and either lacks the background or misunderstands some of the aspects of biotechnology in general.  Now, here are the things in the video that I think were not explained or understood correctly:  - First of all, with current technology YOU CANNOT CREATE VIRUSES FROM ZERO. You always need a virus to start, and then you can modify its genetic material. The hypothetical where you can get viral DNA and create a virus from it is just not possible right now.   - Not all viruses are transmitted through air. In fact, many of the most dangerous viruses currently are transported in some other way, like through body fluids (HIV, Ebola).  - "High school students experimenting with biotech". I think this statement should not have been worded as is. On the video what seems to be implied is that discoveries are being replicated. This is not correct. The original article refers to technologies, such as genome sequencing. Thus the iPhone metaphor is completely wrong, since in the metaphor it would be referring to the machines used to manufacture the iPhone, not the parts of the iPhone.   - "People will start creating viruses because it will be so cheap!". No they won't. Working with viruses is a very difficult and expensive process. Let's say we are working with the assumption that this video is based on, so someone working with viruses that can infect humans. You need a virus to start, which then you can modify and experiment with. Once you have that, you need a tissue where the virus can reproduce. Since it is a virus that can attack humans, you need human tissue. This brings some complexity. It has to be tissue from a tumor, so that cells reproduce and you don't run out of tissue. And the main problem with working with human tissue, is that it is EXTREMELY delicate. You will need a completely sterile environment (which is very expensive), antibiotics and very careful handling, because if any virus or bacteria gets in the tissue it will kill it.  -"Assembling DNA into an artificial virus costs the same as a car". You can't create an artificial virus with current techniques. What the original document is saying is that you can join the DNA pieces into one for $50000, not create a new virus from that DNA.  - Restrict information about viral DNA. Although the nuclear material analogy is good, I think it's incomplete. While restricting access to viral DNA sequences can prevent the kind of dangers you are referring to in this video, it would also cause a massive delay in the development of new measures against new natural pandemics. If nuclear weapons could suddenly appear out of thin air, you'd want as much people to know how to deactivate them as quickly as possible.  -Pandemic detectors. This are not a bad idea in principle, but you make it is sound much easier than they would be to implement. One key flaw I can see in these is that most viruses can't infect humans, so this kind of initiatives can run into a pattern of declaring potential pandemics constantly, so much that no one would pay attention to these.   -"Let's kill all viruses!". That's not a great idea. Although it would cause viral diseases to decrease, it would potentially create more problems than it would solve. Everything has a biological role, including viruses. Viruses specifically have a big role on population control. This can lead to an increase in bacterial population, thus increasing the frequency of bacterial diseases, as well as weakening our immune systems, as they need to encounter minor threats in order to know how to respond to major threats.

They already knew the structure of COVID-19 as it was created using known DNA sequences that produce certain functionality from other viruses such as SARS (0.92), MERS (0.89) and Ebola (0.78) numbers being Cosine similarity-based analysis between COVID-19 and those. Said functionality sequences are well known amongst virologists and are frequently copied and pasted when creating new viruses.  You can think of them as being analogous to functions in programming. Within COVID-19 several DNA sequences that correspond to known functions were identical in their entirety, which would be statistically impossible to happen naturally.

There was a study done by the US on how hard it would be for technically competent people to build a nuclear bomb and how long it would take with only open source information.   About 3 years and the physics graduates with zero specific knowledge of nuclear physics prior submitted their work as part of the study and they had independently recreated the designs of working nuclear bombs. It was also demonstrated that these could be manufactured without an advanced nuclear industry. The technology to either enrich uranium or breed other fissile material suitable for a fission bomb is widely available.   There are also tens of thousands of orphan sources out there including large amounts of plutonium unaccounted for. Building a nuclear bomb is extremely challenging but also technically possible. Building a radiological weapon is relatively easy. There is tonnes of radioactive ceasium out there and some of the worst nuclear accidents and hazards came from accidental releases of ceasium.   It's also possible to do enormous damage via other means such as interfering with drinking water treatment plants. Dump a bunch of the additives in there and dupe the sensors with a sophisticated cyber attack and you could poison a city. Disable the treatment plants in a similar way and introduce existing common nasty pathogens.   I agree accidental release of a pathogen worse than covid is probably the greatest real risk in the short term but the relative risk isn't that much higher than nuclear or cyber technologies.

nobody: Not a single soul: My mind drifting away from a conversation: 3:16
As an aspiring Bio-Student with an interest especially in the very wide field you talked about in the vid, I quite liked the videos concept.   However, I'd like to point out some things I think should be addressed:  Firstly, Gene-therapy, while already in-use, is still somewhat uncommon, which the video glossed over. On the other hand, it's relevance will only grow so not that big of an issue.     Secondly, the image of "Teenagers being asked to build an IPhone for homework" is imho a bit misleading, as you still need a properly equipped lab to do it. Asking teenagers in school to on their own do a plasmid transfection for example would lead to a lot of frustrated teenagers (not even talking about storage procedures for DNA and such.)  Also, a lot of the verification procedures [such as Gel-Electrophoresis] use slightly and less slightly dangerous substances which adolescents usually aren't allowed to handle on their own, if at all. If you're talking about teenagers in their free time who have an exceptional interest in the matter doing it while being supported by, for instance, a research lab in the area, that would be a bit more accurate).      Another small nitpick would be that the lab equipment you're probably talking about is... incomplete. You of course can just use the stuff but if you really wanted to kill off a large portion of humanity, I'd reccommend you also verify that your Bioweapon can indeed do that and that you were successful in building what you want to in the first place (Biotech can be iffy to work with and there's the inside joke of some cell cultures being downright waiting for an opportunity to perish). And a lab, even disregarding safety levels (I'll get to that shortly) equipped to do all of that will cost more than just a few ten thousand dollar/euros (which I interpreted as the price range for the average car. If you're talking  about luxury carriages, maybe. For reference, one proper pipette (not the pasteur-pipettes, the good ones) already costs somewhere between 100 to 1000 euros).    You also need the lab in first place and some good excuse for ordering the really dangerous stuff. Which you're only allowed to work on in restricted laboratories (for example, there's only 4 labs with the needed security level (S-4) in germany.) Also, nitpick again, in the part regarding the combination of potentially deadly viruses, the scientist depicted should probably wear more safety equipment. A normal mask and glass ain't cutting it anymore when you're dealing with that level of danger.   And, my greatest issue with the video: Many of the safety measures you proposed are already implemented one way or another. Just look up how an S-4 lab is secured.    Also, nitpick again, the idea of using UV for example is not new, it's used for decontamination quite often. If you wanted to use it near people though... consider that UV doesn't care if it fries a virus, a bacterium or your skin cells.   Nonetheless, this is (again, imho) an video showing both the potential and potential risks of biotechnology, which should not be understated.

Nuclear weapons tech is treated by most of the world's governments as an "intrinsic secret," information that _by default_ is classified and restricted no matter who and when and where it was created (even and _especially_ if civilians with no connections to government/defense are responsible), so as to not allow uncontrolled access by bad actors. If I develop a new warhead geometry that improves nuclear weapon yields, for example, since I live in the US the first thing that would happen is I'd be paid visits by the NRC and Defense Security Service to look into both my safety protocols and my information security practices, and they would want to also speak to everyone else with any knowledge of my work to ensure there's a clearly defined chain of access to that knowledge.  Certain types of biological data - like virus and viral payload gene sequences - could, and should, be treated similarly. The systems and mechanisms already exist to do it.

I am a PhD student in essentially virology. This video is shallow, imprecise, fear-mongering and got quite a few important things inaccurately or incorrectly. Here are the few points I noticed: 1. Itâ€™s probably impossible to do this DNA order tracing - people can just order short pieces and stitch them together like how high school students can learn to do. 2. Itâ€™s really quite difficult to make a virus more deadly/infectious in lab. Most people just experiment with a few point mutations, which almost never result in a virus that is more fit to replicate in humans. Even doing recombinations donâ€™t work most of the times. You talking about this loosely also make scientists that do well-meaning and very important experiments being attacked by the public. I remember listening to a TWiV episode and hearing a scientist receiving extremely derogatory emails from the public for doing some standard experiments with SARS-CoV-2 that are very important to help understanding how Omicron is more infectious. 3. Vaccine development is just slow. It was lucky for SARS-CoV-2 we had some very important findings from trying to develop a vaccine for SARS-CoV-1 over a decade ago (mostly those two proline mutations in the spike). It was not intuitive and may simple need longer for other vaccines to develop. Clinical trials also just has to take that long. I am not an expert in that but I canâ€™t imagine the whole process being shortened to just a few months - to see the short term safety effects it just takes time.  I think you might have gotten the idea for the video from some old advisory letter to Obama or something like it. It was OK and makes a lot of sense to us who study the subject, but talking about it to the public should require a lot more understanding than what this video presented to avoid confusions. One minor quibble: there's a pretty compelling school of thought that says mass vaccination is counterproductive to pandemic response.  You're basically inviting the virus, on a mass scale, to learn how to bypass the vaccine.    The best response, this school states, is to vaccinate the vulnerable -- those who have a very high likelihood of dying from the disease.  Everybody else -- even those who will be hit hard by it -- should just get the disease and let their immune systems do a better job of destroying it. One of the rare kurzgesagt L's in my opinion - restricting information flow is rarely effective and often has worse side effects than its original goal. The same will be true for biotech, and fear mongering about open dna stores will only hinder progress for people trying to help

It seems a bit naÃ¯ve to assume we can contain the spread of biotech anything like we did with Nuclear.  The nuclear situation has the benefit that it's just hard to get hold of or refine uranium is other similar fissile material, and that could be physically enforced, and detected easily. By comparison, with biotech, the building blocks of viruses are a small number of common amino-acids, that exist in all the living material around us. It's pretty obvious why a bioweapon would be far more destructive than nuclear weapons. After all, you only need to make it self-replicating and deploy it at least once. Nuclear weapons tend to not really be good at duplicating themselves without billions of dollars of investment and deploying them is rather flashy. If anything, the hazy origins of SARS-CoV-1 and -2 should be a warning that if a virus ever gets weaponised, we're unlikely to figure out who did it.  Tracing viruses is much harder than nuclear weapons and radioactive material, too. You can't exactly put a Geiger counter next to a sample to check whether it contains viral matter. And you only may need a tiny vial to kickstart a pandemic that will kill billions. Much better for an end-of-the-world doom scenario than some dinky 'thermonuclear war' scenario that requires at least two superpowers, one of whom is decidedly suicidal.
